rememberedPersonSummary.name: Joy Learmouth
story:
On the 23rd October mum went to sleep for the last time. She will be loved and missed by all who knew her.

St Luke's Hospice were a lifeline for mum in her last few years, they picked her up once a week and took her to the centre for the day where she would play games, be creative, have a scrumptious lunch and get advice and care from the Macmillan nurses.  She really looked forward to her weekly visits and would recount them for many days afterwards. She loved that she didn't have to rely on anyone else to get there and really enjoyed her time there. She was also very appreciative of the support the MacMillan nurses gave her whilst she was there.  

The MacMillan nurses were also extremely supportive to her at home if she had any concerns or couldn't be seen by the doctor.  They were also our lifeline in her last few weeks, ensuring that her pain was correctly managed. They liaised with, and visited her in the care home to ensure she was as comfortable as possible, when we couldn't because of COVID 19 restrictions. In the absence of being able to get a doctor out in 7 hours, the MacMillan nurses also came out to certify mum's death. They then spent some time with us, explaining the next steps and offering support and guidance in our hour of need. We can't thank them enough.

Mum asked that instead of people sending flowers for her funeral, that they help to raise funds for St Luke's Hospice and MacMillan nurses in order that others may continue to be able to use, enjoy and be helped by their services.

story:
My dad, Roy, has been diagnosed with a High-Grade Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma which requires immediate, aggressive treatment. Naturally, I have felt really low about this news (along with the ongoing pandemic) and need something to help me through. So, I have decided to cycle for at least 30 minutes everyday through the entire time my dad recieves treatment. This will hopefully lift my mood and give me something to focus on.

Receiving donations for this challenge will not only hold me accountable (and make me actually do it) but will also raise funds for the chairty supporting my dad through this. On diagnosis he was provided with a Macmillan nurse who we can all contact if we need anything at all, from advice to emotional support (pretty amazing in my opinion).

Please give as generously as you can and provide me with that extra push. Thank you.

P.S. the only excuse I will give myself is childcare and snow/ice, in which case I will make up lost time :)

story:
Thanks for visiting my page.  During 2021, I'll be raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.  I have set myself two targets for the year:

1) Cycle a total of 2000 km during the year using my mountain and exercise bikes.

2) Walk / hike a total of 1500 km during the year either outdoors or on my treadmill.

To achieve this, I'll be taking part in a series of distance walking challenges throughout the year and you'll be able to follow my progress, using the Strava feed I've connected to this page.  Heart condition research is important to me and I have had several family members suffer with various diseases.  Both my parents suffered from conditions into which the BHF does research.  My Dad, who passed away in 1995, suffered for many years with Vascular Disease and Angina.  My Mum, who died earlier this year, suffered from Vascular Dementia.  This challenge is in memory of them, as much as it is to help others who continue to suffer.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives.  It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures.  £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target.  Thanks!

story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas!

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Altrincham Fundraising Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community. 

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! 

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas. 

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas!

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Eastbourne and Pevensey Fundraising Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community. 

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! 

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas. 

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
Help us raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas! 

During December hundreds of our fundraising dogs across the UK would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at supermarket and street collections, Christmas fairs and festive coffee mornings. Our four-legged fundraisers support the 400+ fundraising groups across the UK from Glasgow to Plymouth and everywhere in between.

Due to the current situation, most of our fundraising groups will not be out collecting this festive season, and our four-legged fundraisers will be very much missed! We hope you will do your bit and help us as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! Heres how you can join in: 

	Donate £12 and share our posts across social media nominating a friend, family member or colleague to  get involved

	Set up your own fundraiser on this page

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas!

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Canterbury Fundraising Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community. 

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! 

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas. 

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
Help us raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas! 

During December hundreds of our fundraising dogs across the UK would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at supermarket and street collections, Christmas fairs and festive coffee mornings. Our four-legged fundraisers support the 400+ fundraising groups across the UK from Glasgow to Plymouth and everywhere in between.

Due to the current situation, most of our fundraising groups will not be out collecting this festive season, and our four-legged fundraisers will be very much missed! We hope you will do your bit and help us as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! Heres how you can join in: 

	Donate £12 and share our posts across social media nominating a friend, family member or colleague to  get involved

	Set up your own fundraiser on this page

story:
100 for Guide Dogs is your challenge, your way. You can choose to Run100, Cycle100 or Swim100 between 1 July and 31 November. However you take on your 100, get sponsored to do it and help us supporting people living with sight loss. 

You could complete 100 metres, 100 minutes, 100 days  be creative!

The sponsorship money you raise will make a difference. £100 could pay for five hours' training at a Guide Dogs training school.

It's thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services, like our guide dogs, to people with sight loss. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

#TeamGuideDogs

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Miriam  Whitmore
story:
On the 1st of November my family life changed forever when, my Mum, Miriam passed away. I was very fortunate at these troubled times that I was able to spend that little remaining time saying goodbye. During this time we discussed a lot of things that covered her funeral and beyond that. It was a dying wish by her that no flowers would be bought for her. Plus instead of buying her flowers a donation would be made to a charity instead. So it was decided by me that a donation to Great Ormond Street Hospital would seem like the best option.  Miriam would be please with my choice of charity as she always loved children and helping them would be something she would do.

Many Thanks

Lewis

story:
I wasn’t planning on doing this. Not the fundraising, not even the cycling. But then Covid happened and changed everything.

I suddenly realised a few months ago that I couldn’t “just go” abroad anymore- and that made me a bit sad. At the same time, I (like a lot of us!) was eating a bit too much in lockdown #1 and getting less active. So, in late Summer, I decided to get on my exercise bike. 

What started out as daily 5km rides to improve my fitness soon became daily 20-25 mile rides... but, despite the improved fitness, I felt like something was missing. I needed to “go” somewhere- to complete a tangible journey...yes, it’d have to be a virtual one, but I needed it to be real. I needed to complete a Pandemicathon! 

Which is when I decided to virtually take on the epic 874 mile ride from John O’Groats to Lands End. I successfully completed that on 10 October 2020... and on 11 October started the next leg of my Pandemicathon.

I took a virtual ferry from Lands End, Cornwall to Brest, France. I then started Leg 2 and departed Brest for the Portuguese capital, Lisbon. It’s a massive 1,150+ mile bike ride - although my final mileage will depend on the exact route I take and any detours I might make along the way, as I virtually explore France, Spain and Portugal... I rather suspect detours might happen around Cognac, Bordeaux and Rioja... 🍷but do please feel free to recommend other places for me to “visit” on my ride! 

I hope the prospect of me cycling 2000+ miles across Europe might be worthy of some pennies for a great cause! If my little legs make it, who knows where I’ll go afterwards... But I’ll keep peddling while the money is being raised.

Anyway, you can see my whole journey up to this point by following me on Strava - where I’ve posted pictures of the places I’ve been. And from today onwards, Strava will update this page too. 

Cancer Research does such great work as they strive to beat cancer. I watched the Stand Up To Cancer Gogglebox and was so moved by the stories that I decided to do my bit to try to help beat this horrible disease. I know lots of people who have been affected by cancer - I’m sure you do too. Please help support their efforts to find a cure.

Pierina was a wholly beautiful person and she radiated warmth and comfort. She was amazing. One of a kind. Gorgeous (her favourite word!). She gave the best hugs.

She was also not afraid of telling you just how much she loved you and she shared your pain and hurt as if it were her own. If she could have taken it on herself she would have and without a second thought.

She was the heart and soul of our family and everyone’s biggest fan and supporter. Our lives (and those of the people she loved and cared for) were full of praise, admiration and so much love, and that love made you feel so special. She built you up and never ever knocked you down. Pierina was always there for anyone who asked - she would do anything for you.

Everyone deserves a Pierina in their lives. She was the life and soul of the party and a perpetual happy thread in all the lives she touched.

In remembrance of Pierina, a loving wife, mother, mother-in-law. grandmother, great-grandmother, sister, sister-in-law, aunt, great-aunt, godmother and friend, please help us raise money for this wonderful charity which is so close to our hearts.

story:
At the Marie Curie Hospice, Liverpool, we give expert care to people with a terminal illness, and their loved ones every day of the year. Our hospice team includes doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, social workers and many more, and is supported by local people who freely volunteer their time and energy to help us run the hospice.

As well as being a place where people can stay to get the expert care they need in a friendly and homely setting, we also support people visiting with clinics and therapies. These include yoga, exercise classes and relaxation. People using the day unit can also get together over a freshly cooked lunch from our chefs.

Relatives and friends can visit any time of the day or night, and stay with their loved ones if they wish to. 

We need to raise £6,397 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in in Liverpool, get the care and support they need.

It's going to be great fun and features a Christmas raffle, with some fantastic prizes on offer as well as the opportunity to have a ride on the Crogga Valley Railway - just be sure to wrap up warm!

story:
We are the Ballycotton Fundraising Branch, we run a number of events throughout the year including the Champion Concert. We have activity on the pier for the August Bank holiday weekend. We also hold collections in Aldi stores in Midletown and Carrigtohill for our national fundraiser Mayday. We have many supporters in our community and are very grateful of their ongoing support, especially during the current difficult times.

The Ballycotton Lifeboat station was established by the Institution in 1858 to afford protection to the shipping frequenting the port of Cork and together with the new stations at Youghal and Ardmore (closed 1895) and others contemplated to guard the English and Irish Channels. The crews at Ballycotton have been presented with 19 awards for gallantry – the most recent in 2002. For another rescue in 1936, Gold, Silver and Bronze medals were all awarded.

Keeping our Ballycotton lifeboat maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. During the pandemic we have still been offering a lifesaving service and are continuing to raise vital funds. However we haven’t been able to take part in our traditional fundraising this year and rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives. Your donation will help support the run the Ballycotton lifeboat.


Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from.
Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

The global fundraiser for UNICEF in 2018 (trekking to Machu Picchu in Peru) was hugely successful and raised £228,500 to support UNICEF Child Protection programmes across the world. The trek brought together 70 partners and staff from more than 30 offices across the firm to take part in a 'once in a lifetime' experience whilst raising significant funds for our global charity partner.

  Overview

The proposed event can accommodate participation by any DLA
Piper partners, staff and clients, anywhere in the world. The participants will embark on 7 days of physical activity of their choice (walking,cycling, running, trekking, swimming, rowing, climbing etc) undertaken in your home city location to raise funds for UNICEF whilst complying with social distancing rules. The event is structured as a virtual challenge with participants committing to achieve a target distance over the seven days. 

Everybody can take part, regardless of your location - individually or in teams - making it fun, competitive and engaging, sharing their fitness schedule via Zoom or through our in-office video conferencing systems where possible.
